p.s: The Sonnet 65 is written by William Shakespeare.
The date of publishment is unknown.
The main theme is that summer is over and winter is arriving slowly.
Sonnet 65 is written in three quatrains and a final couplet.
So in total there are fouteen lines.
All the three quatrains are written with crossrhymes, the final couplet has a pairrhyme.
The metre of all fourteen lines is the iambic pentameter, so in one foot, there is always an unstressed and a stressed syllable.
The first two quatrains are just a long question asked over four verses.
In the first quatrain, the question is how the beautiful summer, which is capable of growing flowers, shall resist the aggressive winter which is powerful enough to destroy strong rocks.
The second quatrain is pretty similar to the first one.

Here the question is how the nice warm days, that Shakespeare describes as summer's honey breath (l. 5) shall be able to hold on against the winter with its cold breezes and frosts when even massive gates of steel can get destroyed.
The last quatrain is different than the first two.
The first question is, where the summer could hide, until winter will be gone and it can show itself again.
The other two questions are, if there is somebody who can defeat the winter or who can hold it back.
The final couplet says, that this would be a miracle (l. 13), but even if it would not happen, the love that is connected to summer will live further on in Shakespeare's sonnets.
